message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of right lower quadrant pain, nausea, and loss of appetite suggest appendicitis, which is most commonly caused by lymphoid hyperplasia in children. Fecalith obstruction is also a possible cause but less common. Ingestion of indigestible object and Meckel diverticulum are not causes of appendicitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation, including the progression of pain to the right lower quadrant, nausea, and loss of appetite, is suggestive of acute appendicitis. Among the options, lymphoid hyperplasia is the most common cause of acute appendicitis in children. Fecalith obstruction and Meckel diverticulum are less common causes, and ingestion of an indigestible object is not a cause of acute appendicitis.

Among the options, only lymphoid hyperplasia is a common cause of acute appendicitis in children. Fecalith obstruction and Meckel diverticulum are possible causes of abdominal pain, but their occurrence is less common compared to acute appendicitis. Ingestion of an indigestible object is unlikely to be the cause of symptoms in this case.
